title: WebQ
text:
These are notes for creating and editing websites using Quarto. This site resides on the ykwongsuss.github.io page and contains branches to other study websites as listed below.
Quarto Notes:

yaml
qmd
R
julia
tex
tikz
graphviz

Websites:

ykwongWebR: R Basics
ykwongWebJ: Julia Basics
ykwongWebStats: Mathematical Statistics with R
ykwongWebNPar: NonParametric Statistics with R
ykwongWebSurv: Survival Analysis with R
ykwongWebLA: Linear Algebra with Julia

title: yaml
text:
3 Navigation sidebar in _quarto.yml
---
project:
  type: website

website:
  title: "WebQuarto"
  page-navigation: true
  sidebar:
    search: true
    contents:
      - section: Notes
        href: index.qmd
        contents:
          - text: yaml
            href: notes/yaml.qmd
          - text: qmd
            href: notes/qmd.qm
   ...

title: Q markdown
text:
Quarto is a file format that is supported by RStudio and Positron (based on VSCode). The file extension for a Quarto document is .qmd .
Quarto allows markdown to be written directly. Markdown includes text formatting, images and mathematical symbols. You can include TeX in markdown using embedded $ or $$ tags (inline or display modes).
With code chunks, Quarto further supports both computational codes (R, Python and Julia) and descriptive codes (LaTeX, Mermaid and GraphViz). Type backslash / in Quarto to see the selections.
Quarto extensions also allow for special support such as Tikz.
Quarto output is usually written to HTML or PDF formats as per YAML instructions.

title: Q markdown
text:
Footnotes


A footnote marker cannot contain spaces.↩︎

title: computeBlocks
text: The main compute blocks are R, Julia and Python. These are created using forward slash in Quarto’s Visual mode editing or ```Rfor example.

title: computeBlocks

2 Div Block
{/ Div... } can format with css html

2.1 Div block - embed TeX

\[
\int udv = uv - \int vdu
\]



2.2 Div Block - css and padding

\(\textbf{Gosset's Theorem}\)
If \(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n\) is a random sample from a \(N(\mu, \sigma)\) distribution, then the rv
\[
\frac{\bar X - \mu}{S/\sqrt{n}}
\]
has the t distribution with (n-1) degrees of freedom, \(t_{n-1}.\)

\(\textbf{Gosset's Theorem}\)
If \(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n\) is a random sample from a \(N(\mu, \sigma)\) distribution, then the rv

has the t distribution with (n-1) degrees of freedom, \(t_{n-1}.\)

title: Selected TeX Codes
Selected TeX Codes
Selected TeX Codes
text:
2 Definitions, propositions and theorems

are usually placed in a fenced qmd div block
css style: border: 1pt black solid; padding: 6pt
math notation in TeX may be used in qmd
no cross referencing below. Just use qmd double asterisks for bold def.


Definition 3.4.3 A subspace of \(\mathbb{W}\) of \(\mathbb{R^n}\) is a set of vectors such that for every \(c \in \mathbb{R^n}\) and for every \(\mathbf{uv} \in \mathbb{W}\), then

\(\mathbf{0} \in \mathbb{W}\)
\(\mathbf{u + v} \in \mathbb{W}\)
c\(\mathbf{u} \in \mathbb{W}\)

When these properties hold we say that \(\mathbb{W}\) is closed under addition and scalar multiplication.

# this is a code-block

div-ID : #thm-line; 
#lem-; #cor-; #prp; #cnj-; #def-; 
#exm-; #exr-; #sol-; #rem-
.proof

2.0.1 Cross referencing a theorem and proof in div

#thm-line is used to cross reference displaying Theorem 1
.proof is a class in the div block
a tex-block is used for the displayed equation (4.5)
tex commands: \qquad\blacksquare and \tag{4.5} are used


Theorem 1 \[\int_0^\infty x^{\alpha-1}e^{-x/\beta} dx  = \Gamma(\alpha) \tag{4.5}\]


Proof. Make the substitution \(u= x/\beta\), so that \(x=\beta u\) and \(dx = \beta du\):
\[\begin{align*}
    \int_0^\infty x^{\alpha-1}e^{-x/\beta} dx
     &=  \int_0^\infty (\beta u)^{\alpha-1} e^{-u} \beta du \\[12pt]
   & = \int_0^\infty u^{\alpha-1}e^{-u} du \\[12pt]
   & = \int_0^\infty x^{\alpha-1}e^{-x} dx \\[12pt]
   & = \Gamma(\alpha) \qquad\blacksquare
\end{align*}\]

Make the substitution $u = x/\beta$, so that $x=\beta u$ and $dx = \beta du$: 
\begin{align*}
    \int_0^\infty x^{\alpha-1}e^{-x/\beta} dx 
     &=  \int_0^\infty (\beta u)^{\alpha-1} e^{-u} \beta du \\[12pt]
   & = \int_0^\infty u^{\alpha-1}e^{-u} du \\[12pt]
   & = \int_0^\infty x^{\alpha-1}e^{-x} dx \\[12pt]
   & = \Gamma(\alpha) \qquad\blacksquare \tag{4.5}
 \end{align*}


2.1 TeX Block - \boxed equations
Integration by parts:
\[\begin{equation}
  \boxed{ \int udv = uv - \int vdu }
\end{equation}\]
\begin{equation}
  \boxed{ \int udv = uv - \int vdu }
\end{equation}

title: Selected TeX Codes
text:
3 TeX Tables

3.1 TeX Block - Tex-table using array
Example Collett 1 - Table 2.7
\[\begin{array}{c c c c }
\hline
\text{Group} & \text{Number of Deaths} & \text{Number Surviving} & \text{Number at Risk} \\
      & \text{at $t_{(j)}$} & \text{beyond $t_{(j)}$} & \text{just before $t_{(j)}$} \\
\hline
\rm{I} & d_{1j} & n_{1j}-d_{1j} & n_{1j} \\
\rm{II} & d_{2j} & n_{2j}-d_{2j} & n_{2j} \\
\hline
\text{Total} & d_{j} & n_{j}-d_{j} & n_{j} \\
\hline
\end{array}\]
note: tabular not supported, use array to form a Tex-table
\begin{array}{c c c c } 
\hline 
\text{Group} & \text{Number of Deaths} & \text{Number Surviving} & \text{Number at Risk} \\ 
      & \text{at $t_{(j)}$} & \text{beyond $t_{(j)}$} & \text{just before $t_{(j)}$} \\ 
\hline
\rm{I} & d_{1j} & n_{1j}-d_{1j} & n_{1j} \\ 
\rm{II} & d_{2j} & n_{2j}-d_{2j} & n_{2j} \\ 
\hline
\text{Total} & d_{j} & n_{j}-d_{j} & n_{j} \\ 
\hline 
\end{array}


3.2 TeX block with Div block over it
# div-block - style=border: 1px solid; background:white; padding-right:1cm

\[\begin{align}
Sample\ mean\\
  \bar x &= \frac{\sum x_i}{n} \tag{1.1}\\
  
Sample\ variance\\
  S^2 &= \frac{\sum (X_i - \bar X)}{n-1}. \tag{1.2}
\end{align}\]

title: computeBlocks
text: 3 Python Code chunk

title: rCodeChunk
text:
R compute chunk is the default computational engine for Quarto. No further action is necessary except to place the R code in the code chunk generated by /R.
The basic R Code chunks features are indciated below:

0.1 Comments

# comment are preceded with hashtag
qnorm(0.95)

[1] 1.644854




0.2 Chunk options
Can be place within the parenthesized r statement, or in the main statement preceded by the code option symbols: #| eval: false

# eval: false
qnorm(0.95)

[1] 1.644854


(no output)

version$version.string

[1] "R version 4.5.1 (2025-06-13)"

title: rCodeChunk
text:
1 R Code chunk

# comment
qnorm(0.95)

[1] 1.644854


Chunk options can be indicated inside the r parenthesis or using #| eval: false , in the header for example.

qnorm(0.95)

(no output)

version$version.string

[1] "R version 4.5.0 (2025-04-11)"

title: juliaCodeChunk
text:
Julia code chunks may be used “directly” without additional statements in the yaml. If using with R code chunks for example, it may be necessary to load Julia code chunk first.
Julia code chunk may be indicated from quarto’s Visual mode / command or from ```julia for example

0.1 Adding Julia Package

title: juliaCodeChunk
text:
1 Julia Code chunk

# julia comments are indicated by the pound sign
1+1

2



1.1 Adding Julia Package

import Pkg; 
Pkg.add("Pipe");
using Pipe

title: julia
text: Julia code chunks may be used “directly” without additional statements in the yaml. Julia code chunk may be indicated from quarto’s Visual mode /julia command.

title: R
text:
R compute chunk is the default computational engine for Quarto. No further action is necessary. Just place the R code in the code chunk generated by /R.
The basic R Code chunks features are indicated below:

title: version
text:
To find out what packages and tools are installed in your Quarto environment, the following commands are available at the terminal prompt.
quarto check
quarto tools



quarto --version
julia --version
R --version
python3 --version
tex --version



tlmgr info *what*
tlmgr update --list
tlmgr update all
e.g.
tlmgr info --list
tlmgr info pgfplots  (1.18.1)
tlmgr info luatex
tlmgr update tex
tlmgr install pagecolor



\documentclass{article}
\usepackage{pgfplots}
\pgfplotsset{compat=1.15} 
\begin{document}
   \pgfplotsversion
\end{document}

title: Tikz
text:
install danmackinlay extension on project folder. Run the code below using Terminal.
quarto add danmackinlay/quarto_tikz
this will install the extension under the _extensions subdirectory. Check using directory command ls.
include in yaml
filters: 
  - tikz
create a code block with class .tikz
```tikz

title: GraphViz
text:
Example code chunk with GraphViz(dot)
{dot}
//| fig-width: 4
//| fig-height: 2
digraph {
  rankdir = LR;
  node [shape=circle, fixedsize=true, width=0.7, fontname=roboto];
  edge [color=brown,minlen=2, fontname=roboto]
    
    A [fillcolor=lightblue, style=filled, label="nodeA"]
    B [fillcolor=yellow, style=filled, label="B"]
    D [shape=rect, fillcolor=orange, style=filled]
    A -> C [label=13]
    B -> C [label=12]
    C -> D [label=11]    
}

title: Tikz
Q markdown
text:
1 Basic Markdown
Some basic formatting in a list:

*italics* – italics
**bold** – bold
`highlight` — highlight (backticks)


URLs: [desc](URL)
URL1: 5 min Strategy
WebPage: ykwongSUSS.github.io


Selected Code Chunks and Code Blocks
Computational Code Chunks are available for R,Python, Julia. Other code chunks include support for Mermaid, GraphViz . Some of these are detailed in accompanying References. Type backslash / to see the selections (under visual editor of RStudio).
Code Blocks (descriptive) are available to cater to TeX, HTML, Line, Div and Raw .
Example code chunk with GraphViz(dot)










A

nodeA



C

C



A->C


13



B

B



B->C


12



D

D



C->D


11








*Note: cell options #| for {r} ; //| for {dot} ; %%/ for {mermaid}
{dot}
//| fig-width: 4
//| fig-height: 2
digraph {
  rankdir = LR;
  node [shape=circle, fixedsize=true, width=0.7, fontname=roboto];
  edge [color=brown,minlen=2, fontname=roboto]
    
    A [fillcolor=lightblue, style=filled, label="nodeA"]
    B [fillcolor=yellow, style=filled, label="B"]
    D [shape=rect, fillcolor=orange, style=filled]
    A -> C [label=13]
    B -> C [label=12]
    C -> D [label=11]    
}

1.1 Markdown or LaTeX
Formulas and equations can be written in qMarkdown /math or a LaTeX block /tex (or even in a Typst block). Math inline and display modes can be used in qMarkdown but it is better to use a TeX block for multi-line equations. More at the LaTeX reference note.

Use markdown math mode
Theorem: For any \(\alpha, \beta > 0\)

\[
\int_0^\infty x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x/\beta} dx = \beta^\alpha \Gamma(\alpha)
\]

Use TeX code block
Proof: Substitute \(u=x/\beta\) so that \(x=\beta u\) and \(dx = \beta\ du\)

\[\begin{align*}
   \int_0^\infty x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x/\beta} dx &= \int_0^\infty (\beta u)^{\alpha-1} e^{-u} \beta du \\[6pt]
   &= \beta^\alpha \int_0^\infty u^{\alpha-1} e^{-u} du \\[6pt]
   &= \beta^\alpha \Gamma(\alpha)  \qquad\blacksquare
\end{align*}\]
\begin{align*}
   \int_0^\infty x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x/\beta} dx 
     &= \int_0^\infty (\beta u)^{\alpha-1} e^{-u} \beta du \\[6pt]
     &= \beta^\alpha \int_0^\infty u^{\alpha-1} e^{-u} du  \\[6pt]
     &= \beta^\alpha \Gamma(\alpha)  \qquad\blacksquare
\end{align*}


1.2 Footnote
Devore’s book as a footnote.1
… the footnote is usually written on the next line but will appear at the bottom of the page as a footnote. This footnote is in QMarkdown. A LaTeX footnote is different and has a separate \footnote command. Tip: check for extra backslashes if footnote is not working.
Devore’s book. [^1]

[^1]: Devore, Jay L, Kenneth N Berk, Matthew A Carlton, et al. 
2021. Modern Mathematical Statistics with Applications. 
Vol. 285. Springer.

title: Q markdown

1.5 Math support
The area of a circle is $\pi r^2$ (inline).
Binomial function (display):
  $$ f(k) = \binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!} $$
The area of a circle is \(\pi r^2\) (inline).
Binomial function (display):
\[ f(k) = \binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!} \]


1.6 Footnotes in Qmd
This paragraph has a footnote [^here] described and reference 
at the next paragraph but not visible here. The actual footnote 
appears at the end of this page. A LaTeX footnote is different 
and has a separate \footnote command. Tip: check for extra
backslashes if footnote is not working.

[^here]: A footnote marker cannot contain spaces.
This paragraph has a footnote 1 described and reference at the next paragraph but not visible here. The actual footnote appears at the end of this page. A LaTeX footnote is different and has a separate \footnote command. Tip: check for extra backslashes if footnote is not working.

title: Q markdown
section: 2 Selected Code Chunks and Code Blocks
text:
2 Selected Code Chunks and Code Blocks
Computational Code Chunks are available for R,Python, Julia. Other code chunks include support for Mermaid, GraphViz . Some of these are detailed in accompanying References. Type backslash / to see the selections (under visual editor of RStudio).
Code Blocks (descriptive) are available to cater to TeX, HTML, Line, Div and Raw .

2.1 Markdown or LaTeX
Formulas and equations can be written in qMarkdown /math or a LaTeX block /tex (or even in a Typst block). Math inline and display modes can be used in qMarkdown but it is better to use a TeX block for multi-line equations. More at the LaTeX reference note.

Use markdown math mode
Theorem: For any \(\alpha, \beta > 0\)

\[
\int_0^\infty x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x/\beta} dx = \beta^\alpha \Gamma(\alpha)
\]

Use TeX code block
Proof: Substitute \(u=x/\beta\) so that \(x=\beta u\) and \(dx = \beta\ du\)

\[\begin{align*}
   \int_0^\infty x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x/\beta} dx &= \int_0^\infty (\beta u)^{\alpha-1} e^{-u} \beta du \\[6pt]
   &= \beta^\alpha \int_0^\infty u^{\alpha-1} e^{-u} du \\[6pt]
   &= \beta^\alpha \Gamma(\alpha)  \qquad\blacksquare
\end{align*}\]
\begin{align*}
   \int_0^\infty x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x/\beta} dx 
     &= \int_0^\infty (\beta u)^{\alpha-1} e^{-u} \beta du \\[6pt]
     &= \beta^\alpha \int_0^\infty u^{\alpha-1} e^{-u} du  \\[6pt]
     &= \beta^\alpha \Gamma(\alpha)  \qquad\blacksquare
\end{align*}


2.2 Footnote
Devore’s book as a footnote.2
… the footnote is usually written on the next line but will appear at the bottom of the page as a footnote. This footnote is in QMarkdown. A LaTeX footnote is different and has a separate \footnote command. Tip: check for extra backslashes if footnote is not working.
Devore’s book as a footnote. [^2]

[^2]: Devore, Jay L, Kenneth N Berk, Matthew A Carlton, et al. 
2021. Modern Mathematical Statistics with Applications. 
Vol. 285. Springer.

title: GraphViz
text:
Example code chunk with GraphViz(dot)
{dot}
//| fig-width: 4
//| fig-height: 2
digraph {
  rankdir = LR;
  node [shape=circle, fixedsize=true, width=0.7, fontname=roboto];
  edge [color=brown,minlen=2, fontname=roboto]
    
    A [fillcolor=lightblue, style=filled, label="nodeA"]
    B [fillcolor=yellow, style=filled, label="B"]
    D [shape=rect, fillcolor=orange, style=filled]
    A -> C [label=13]
    B -> C [label=12]
    C -> D [label=11]    
}
*Note: cell options #| for {r} ; //| for {dot} ; %%/ for {mermaid}

title: R
text:
1 R Code Chunk

1.1 Comments
{r echo=FALSE}
# uses BaseR function
qnorm(0.95)


[1] 1.644854




1.2 Chunk options

1.2.1 eval: FALSE
Can be place within the parenthesized r statement, or in the main statement preceded by the code option symbols: #| eval: false
{r}
#| eval: FALSE
qnorm(0.95)
(no output)


1.2.2 code-fold: TRUE
{r}
#| code-fold: TRUE

library(tidyverse)
library(here)
theme_set(theme_bw())


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(here)
theme_set(theme_bw())




1.2.3 Figure, Caption options
{r}
#| fig.width: 4
#| fig.height: 3
#| cap-location: margin
#| fig-cap: "Figure half the width"

library(tidyverse)
ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, color=Species))+
  geom_point(show.legend=FALSE)+
  ggtitle("From Iris Database")





Note: Figure half the width.

You can also place tables in the margin of your document by specifying column: margin. kable allows for striped rows - handy for small tables like this.
{r}
#| column: margin

knitr::kable(
  mtcars[1:6, 1:3]
)



2.2 Column Margins
Set aside some text, math or images in the margin. In this case, it is a side comment that does not detract for the main proof.


We know from the first fundamental theorem of calculus that for \(x\) in \([a, b]\):
\[\frac{d}{dx} \left( \int_{a}^{x} f(u)\,du \right)=f(x).\]
::: column-margin
We know from *the first fundamental theorem of calculus* 
that for $x$ in $[a, b]$:

$$\frac{d}{dx} \left( \int_{a}^{x} f(u)\,du \right)=f(x).$$
:::



2.3 Asides
Asides allow you to place content aside from the content it is placed in. Asides look like footnotes, but do not include the footnote mark (the superscript number).
::: aside
This is a span (div) that has the class `aside` which places 
it in the margin without a footnote number.
:::




This is a span (div) that has the class `aside` which places it in the margin without a footnote number.

2 Graphviz Examples

2.1 Simple digraph with labels
{dot}
//| fig-width: 4
//| fig-height: 2
digraph{
  rankdir=TD;
  node[shape=circle, fixedsize=true, width=0.5, fontname=roboto];
  edge[minlen=2]

   {rank=same; A,B,D}  
    A -> B [label=1]
    B -> D [label=1]
    
    A -> C [label=2]
    C -> D [label=3]
  }
}
